reviewText:
Don't buy it, just don't.

The game itself is nice, fancy stalite images and stuff. The reason why you should not buy this is the following:
This game uses not steams licensing model. You need to enter a Serial-Code to unlock it. You get one of them when you buy the game through steam. But as soon do a clean reinstal (for example new OS setup), you have to enter the key again and you get a message saying The key is already in use". I contacted their support three times (with 2-3 weeks between every email) to ask them to reactivate my key. They just ignore you and dont answer. Even when I thread them in the 3rd mail to take legal steps they just ignore you and don't answer.
After that I contacted Steam support and asked for a refund
date:
as I obviously paid for a product I can't use now. They just told me I have to contact the Ikarus (author company of aeroflyFS)...

To this day I still have this game in my library that I waste 50$ on and cant use it because of their bad customer support.
Please do not buy this and do not support such a company! They just want your money and leave you with an unuseable product after!"

reviewText: I always wanted to fly, and I bought aerofly FS a few months before starting real life flying lessons. The idea was to be in a Visual Flight Rules (VFR) airplane and familiarize myself with flying, but skip (unknown) procedural parts. aerofly FS isn’t a full flight simulator like MFSX or X-plane, but to my opinion, it succeeds very well in introducing VFR flying. Flight dynamics are accurate; I spent most in-game time in the Cessna 172 Skyhawk, flying VFR over Switzerland, and landing/taking off at all airstrips. I use real VFR circuit patterns and airspace classification information to add to the experience, and just fly VFR flights from one place to the other. I also do a bit of airwork, e.g. maneuvers (stall recovery, steep turns, slow flight, crosswind landings) and procedures (emergency, circuits), but lack of resistance of joystick/pedals and lack of G-force loadings are not making the experience very close to the real deal. But none of these is the game's fault. In that regard, I miss other AI traffic, radio telephony with ATC, simple procedures (e.g. start the engine, turn on landing lights, VOR navigation), and maybe recording capacities. Few additions are planned, but it is still unclear when and how they will be released. Nevertheless, I love flying & I love aerofly FS. Out.

reviewText: First of all, i don't really find this a simulator, it's basically just FSX gone arcade. First thing i noticed when i was in a plane, there is not one button in the cockpits you can touch, something i love to do is start my planes on my own. You can't even assign keys to like Fuel Pump and such. The game just tosses you on the runway and thats it. There is also no Air Traffic Control and the world is completely dead, there is no traffic what so ever, no other planes, cars, or boats. The towns are also complete wastelands, it looks like they just took google earth scenery from Switzerland and placed them on the game world, and the only place where you can find some buildings is the airports. The graphics look nice but the scenery when you are up close are not nice to look at. From kilometers in the air, they look nice but on the ground not at all, at one point i was taxing off the runway onto a road that looked like someone took a smear of grey that was the road on a smear of green that was suppose to look like grass. This game is not worth it at this price and should be at half its price.

reviewText:
If the Alps looks the same as it does in this simulator in real life then I better pack my bags because Aerofly FS is one of the most beautiful and well optimised simulations out there.

Unfortunately, the detail Aerofly has put into its scenery has meant the sacrifice of detail in the simulation aspect of its simulator. Fuel mixtures, Air Traffic Control, A.I. aircraft and Autopilot are amongst a handful of things that are simply not present in Aerofly FS. It is very clear that Aerofly is meant to be a VFR simulator, with its comparatively small gameworld, small range of aircraft, and lack of radio communication, and whilst this is ultimately all-right, it may deter more experienced simmers from investing a lot of time into it.

Despite lacking in a detailed simulation, however, Aerofly FS has understood and captured the joys of flying and sight-seeing very well. And with its simple control-scheme and variable flight dynamics, its a considerable investment for someone looking to get into the flight-simulation genre.

reviewText:
aerofly FS is a flight sim for beginners and more advanced pilots.
The glider and ultra-light flight simulation is really rather good.
The sim can be used for training approaches and landings with single-engine propeller aircraft as well.
There are plenty of airfields and nice scenery from Switzerland to fly in.

The simulation is not that good for fighter jets, you need to look at DCS for high-quality simulation of those.
However, jets in this can be fun still even if not most accurate flight simulation.

The developers of aerofly also have different product for RC-plane and helicopter simulation and training (hook up RC transmitter to PC for example), if you aim at improving RC skills then that might be better choice.

Depending on what you are after this does have good points and value for money.
For relaxing and training with glider or ultra-light this is a good choice.
For combat with modern jets you need to look at other choices.

reviewText: High quality graphics and very smooth keyboard controls make this an excellent flight sim. The detail on the aircraft itself is impressive, ranging from seeing the steering components actually move to minimal, but visible, damage on the airplane. Landing and taking off is simplified.\n\nThe biggest issue I have with Aerofly is the quality of the environment. Clouds are not highly detailed and the ground is very barren. The occasional cluster of buildings you might fly over (or through), are the large cities
date: while the rest of the landscape has nothing besides Google Earth-like textures. The mountains are nicely done though.\n\nOverall, if you are looking for an easy to pick up, quick to learn flight sim, it's hard to do better than Aerofly FS, but if you are looking for a serious, challenging, realistic flight simulator, look elsewhere, such as MS flight sim. It will entertain you, but not really challenge you.

reviewText:
A very good but basic Flight Sim. The flightmodels are absolutely magnificent a very close replica to the real world equivalents. The default scenery is the best I have ever seen in a flight sim by a large margin especially on the highest of settings. Its a shame that you can only fly within one area and other world locations arent currently present. The number of default aircraft is slightly limited all thoughh it appears there are DLC aircraft available to purchase created by Just Flight (Only 2 at the moment). There is no AI so you are literally flying around by yourself, on a similar note there is currently no multiplayer mode available. That being said I think it is due to be added in the next version/ patch. The weather physics (e.g. Wind) is absolutely brilliant, it feels very much like real life especially through the valleys where there are updrafts and downdrafts & thermals etc, very good. The user interface is easy to use and looks decent. There is good controller detection support as well & the game in general is very easy to setup.

As im sure others have posted it's a great starter or casual sim experience. It is worth noting its simulation experience is probably not on the same level as some products such as FSX, P3D & X-Plane but it is still an excellent product in its own unique way. Would deffinetly recommend to others.

Cheers

reviewText:
I played this game months ago, and it might be some of the reason I am so addicted to other flight sims now.

I played this with a Logitech Extreme3d stick a few months back, and I would recommend using a joystick for any and all flight sims.

This game has some fun achievements that will get you white knuckled at the stick (stay below 500ft for 55 minutes in a jet through the alps??). That kept me busy for a little.

Map isn't as big as I'd hoped when I bought it, but it's set in a beautiful area under the Matterhorn.

Would fly again 9/10

PS I was casual when I flew this and didn't have my a10c hotas, rudder pedals, trackir5, etc etc... just a Logitech Extreme3d from like 1999... also I wasn't into simulating wind so IDK if this game does that.

EDIT: Just reflew with my a10 stick rudder pedals and track IR. all work great, The textures aren't as good as I remember (like a 480 photoreal.. the mountain textures look like potato au'gratin with spinach...) and no good autogen. I can barrel roll and backloop and Immelman (IN A CESSNA 172 BAHAHA) So not too realistic, but fun...

reviewText:
TL;DR: One of the worst flight simulators I've every played.

I've been a fan of Flight Simulators ever since I played Microsoft Flight Simulator X back in 2007, and have been playing various simulators ever since.

Aerofly looks decent, has neat graphics, and looked promising. I managed to fly (and land) the Cessna quite easily.
So what's my problem with this game?

I guess my standards are too high. Flight Simulator X had dozens of planes, and allowed me to fly anywhere in the world. aerofly has a much smaller selection of planes and airport, which was disappointing.

The fact that you can break various parts of your plane (mostly the wings) when crashing looks visually good, but it usually makes no sense: if I slam on the ground too hard, my wings shouldn't fall off. I'd expect an explosion, or my plane stopping to work, but having my wings fall off and the rest of my plane rolling around makes no sense at all.
While we're at the subject of crashing, crashing planes is where the physics engine of this game really shows how bad it is: I don't know if you watched Air Crash Investigation or saw footage from real plane crashes, if you would you would see crashing in this game is nothing like that. when I crash in game, my plane is thrown back into the air upside down, falls again and then the game restarts.

The planes in game were too easy to manouver and did not feel right. The controls are extremely senetive and the planes react so quickly as if they are unaffected by gravity, wind or drag. Calling this a simulation is like calling Just Cause 2's flight mechanics a simulation: it's a balant lie.

On the subject of simulation, there's no Air Traffic Control, no failure simulation, no ability to start in a parking lot and drive your plane there, no control over most of the detailed plane subsystems (Compared to other simulators which allowed me to turn off the engine, or cut off one of the fuel tanks, enable navigation radios, or set trim...).

So my bottom line: not really worth 40$ (and I'm starting to think it wasn't worth the 20$ I paid for it when it was on sale).
